title: Early Childhood Education: Curriculum and Teaching
description: The course aims to introduce the basic principles in curriculum development and practical classroom delivery skills in early childhood education (ECE). Aspects to be covered in the course include 1. Learning and teaching principles of learning areas; 2. Principles and key concepts underpinning the design, implementation, and evaluation of ECE curriculum; 3. Planning developmentally appropriate learning experiences; 4. Skills in delivering quality learning experiences for young children; 5. Assessing the learning of young children; and 6. Adaptation to school life (transition from home to school) and interface between preschool and primary school.(Individual course teachers may update the grade descriptors as and whenever necessary. Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.)
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. Apply the learning and teaching principles of different learning areas when designing learning activities; 2. Understand the principles and key concepts underpinning the design, implementation, and evaluation of ECE curriculum; 3. Demonstrate skills in planning and delivering developmentally appropriate learning experiences for young children;  4. Demonstrate skills in assessing the learning of young children; and  5. Develop programmes facilitating children’s smooth transition from home to school and from preschool to primary education.
syllabus: The course will cover topics such as: 1. Learning and teaching principles of different learning areas, such as Self and Society, Nature and Living, Physical Fitness and Health, Arts and Creativity, Early Childhood Mathematics and Language; 2. Principles and key concepts underpinning the design, implementation, and evaluation of ECE curriculum; 3. Setting age and developmentally appropriate curriculum goals and instructional objectives; 4. Organizing the curriculum in ways to meet the diverse developmental and learning needs of children; 5. Designing child-centered learning activities for children;  6. Skills in delivering quality learning experiences for young children 7. Conducting authentic assessment on children’s learning and developing portfolio to document their learning; and  8. Issues relating to smooth transition from home to school and the interface between preschool and primary school.
required_readings: 1. 王珮玲（1998）：《幼兒發展評量與輔導》。台北：心理出版社。 2. 簡楚瑛 (2005)。《幼兒教育課程模式》。台北：心理出版社。 3. 黃志成、王淑芬、陳玉玟(2008)。《幼兒發展》。台北：楊智文化。 4. 蔣姿儀(2011) ：《幼兒園教保活動與課程》。台北：五南圖書出版公司。
recommended_readings: 1. Abruscato, J. (2004). Teaching Children Science: A discovery Approach. USA: Boston, Pearson Education, Inc.  2. Cryer, D., Harms, T., & Riley, C.(2003).All About The ECERS-R. New York:Teachers College Press. 3. Dionne, S. (2012). Kindergarten monets. Arts & Activities, 151(3), 28-29. 4. Dodge, D. T., Colker, L. J., & Heroman, C. (2002). The creative curriculum for preschool (4th ed.). Washington DC: Teaching Strategies, Inc.  5. Fabian,H. (2002). Children starting school: a guide to sucessful transitions and transfers for teachers and assistants. London :David Fulton. 6. Giallo, R., Treyvaud, K., & Matthews, J. (2010). Hedges, H., Cullen, J., & Jordan, B. (2011). Early years curriculum: Funds of knowledge as a conceptual framework for children’s interests. Journal of Curriculum Studies, 43(2), 185-205.  8. Lim, B. Australasian Journal of Early Childhood, 36(1), 30-35. 11. McLachlan, C., Fleer, M., & Edwards, S. (2013). Early childhood curriculum: Planning, assessment, and implementation (2nd ed.). Cambridge, NY: Cambridge University Press.  12. Morrison, K. (2012). Integrate science and arts process skills in the early childhood curriculum. Dimensions of Early Childhood, 40(1), 31-39. 13. Nielsen, D. M. (2006). Teaching children: A guide to planning your curriculum, teaching through learning centers, and just about everything else (2nd ed.). Thousand Oaks, California: Corwin Press.  14. Niland, A. (2007). Musical stories: Strategies for integrating literature and music for young children. Australian Journal of Early Childhood, 32(4), 7-11. 15. Norris, K., Lucas, L., & Prudhoe, C. (2012). The use of design practice to teach math and science. International Journal of Technology and Design Education,18, 19-44. 17. Rous, B., Hallam, R., McCormick, K., & Cox, M. (2010). Practices that support the transition to public preschool programs: Results from a national survey. Early Childhood Research Quarterly, 25(1), 17-32. 18. Schwartz, S. L., & Copeland, S. M. (2010). Applying technology to inquiry-based learning in early childhood education. Early Childhood Education Journal, 37(5), 381-389. 23. Wortham, S. E. (2002). Early childhood curriculum: developmental bases for learning and teaching (3rd ed.). New Jersey: Merrill Prentice Hall.  24. 成子娟（2004）：《操作式學前數學》，香港，朗文香港教育。 25. 成子娟, Nicola Yelland (主編)　(2005):《香港幼兒教育學報: 數學與科學思維》，第四卷，第一期。 26. 李子建、馬慶堂、黃群英編著 (2005)。《幼兒環境教育：校本課程的經驗》。南京：南京師範大學出版社。 27. 谷瑞勉譯(1999)。鷹架兒童的學習：維高斯基與幼兒教育/原著, Berk, L. K., 新加坡商亞洲湯姆生國際出版有限公司。 30. 黃瑞琴(1996)。《幼兒語文經驗》。台北：五南圖書出版公司。 31. 黃瑞琴(1997)。《幼兒讀寫萌發課程》。台北：五南圖書出版公司。 32. 楊龍立、潘麗珠(2005)。《課程組織：理論與實務》。台北：高等教育文化事業有限公司。 33. 謝鍚金(2006)。《香港幼兒口語發展》。香港：香港大學出版社。 34. 簡楚瑛 (1994)。《方案課程之理論與實務》。台北：心理出版社。

title: Foundations of Early Childhood Education
description: The course aims to introduce the key principles of early childhood education (ECE). Topics to be covered include: 1. basic principles and theories of ECE;2. social and cultural factors influencing ECE;3. ECE approaches: Developmentally Appropriate Practice (DAP), inquiry-based learning, thematic approach, play-based curriculum, project, integrated curriculum, and High/Scope; 4. contemporary ECE issues in Hong Kong; and 5. professional roles of early childhood educators.(Individual course teachers may update the grade descriptors as and whenever necessary. Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.)
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. understand the basic principles and theories of ECE; 2. analyze the diverse social and cultural factors influencing ECE;  3. distinguish the unique features of different ECE approaches; 4. discuss contemporary ECE issues in Hong Kong; and 5. identify the professional roles of early childhood educators.
syllabus: The core content covers: 1. types and goals of ECE services;  2. pioneers and advocators of ECE; 3. learning theories of ECE: e.g. conditional theories, constructivism; 4. basic principles of ECE: child-centeredness, educare; 5. ECE approaches: thematic approach, inquiry-based learning, project, play-based curriculum; 6. different dimensions of professionalism in ECE; 7. socio-cultural factors influencing the ECE service provision in Hong Kong; and  8. contemporary ECE issues in Hong Kong: e.g. 15-year free education, the revised curriculum guide.
required_readings: 1. Baader, M. S. (2004). Froebel and the rise of educational theory in the United States. Studies in Philosophy & Education, 23(5/6), 427-444. 2. Blank, J. (2009). Life in the village: Teacher community and autonomy in an early childhood center. Early Childhood Education Journal, 36, 373-380. 3. Cirtautiene, L. (2016). Australasian Journal of Early Childhood, 42(1), 94-104. 5. Copple, C., & Bredekemp, S. (2009). Developmentally Appropriate Practice in Early Childhood Programs Serving Children from Birth through Age 8. Washington, DC: NAEYC. 6. Court, D. (2010). title: Creative Arts for Early Childhood
description: This course is designed for students to understand the concept of creativity, its theories and the techniques of enhancing creativity, and how adults can facilitate young children’s creative expressions using different forms of arts. These forms comprise visual arts such as drawings and paintings, language arts such as poetry and picture books, expressive arts such as music and dance, as well as the integrated arts. The interrelated development of play, imagination and creativity through the arts is highlighted. Strategies to enhance creative expressions of young children in and outside the school context (i.e. kindergarten, home and community) are also discussed.
outcome: By the end of the course, students are expected to: (i) explain the concept of creativity and its role in the early years of development; (ii) acquire abilities to design activities to enhance children’s creative expressions in various forms of arts; (iii) gain knowledge in assessing creative arts activities and curriculum; (iv) deepen own experience of play as an ideal form for creative expressions; (v) analyze teacher's roles in enhancing children’s creativity   Assessment and its relation to learning outcomes: Essays (50%) - Learning outcomes #1, 2, 3, 4 Presentation (30%) - Learning outcomes #1, 2, 4, 5 Others (classwork) (20%) - Learning outcomes #1, 4, 5

title: Teaching and learning through play in Early Childhood Education
description: The course aims to introduce the characteristics, theories and practices of play as a teaching and learning strategy in ECE. Aspects to be covered in the course include: 1. characteristics of play;2. theories and practices of play;3. values of play for children’s language, cognitive, social, emotional, and physical development; 4. fostering playful learning through formal and informal, indoor and outdoor activities; 5. play and technology; and6. assessing children's learning and development in play.Grade Descriptor: Grade A: Outstanding performance on all learning outcomesGrade B: High performance on some learning outcomesGrade C: Good performance on the majority of the learning outcomesGrade D: Satisfactory performance on the majority of the learning outcomesGrade F: Unsatisfactory performance on the majority of the learning outcomes(Individual course teachers may update the grade descriptors as and whenever necessary. Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.)
outcome: Upon completion of the course, participants should be able to:  1. understand the characteristics, theories and practices of play; 2. design and implement play activities to foster young children’s language, cognitive, social, emotional, and physical development; 3. develop resources for play activities;  4. assess children's learning and development in play.
syllabus: • History and nature of play • Play, Learning and Child Development: Theoretical Perspectives • Values of play for cognitive and social and emotional development • Play and creative expression • Play and science and math • Indoor and outdoor play • Play and Technology • Assessing play and children’s development

title: Educational Management and Sustainable Development of Early Childhood Settings
description: This course provides an introduction to various organizational and management theories to early childhood education practitioners. The application of these theories and knowledge in early childhood education institutions will be illustrated in three levels: the social, school and individual level. First, rationales of accountability and quality assurance mechanism, data driven school improvement and matters in preparation for school self-evaluation and external review are examined. Second, the implementation of school-based management such as resource management, professional development of teachers and team building are discussed. Third, teacher professionalism and ways to equip early childhood practitioners with sufficient knowledge in order to fulfill their respective roles as school leaders or teacher leaders are presented. The course provides participants with conceptual knowledge in school management that serves as the basis of sustainable development of early childhood education institutions.(Individual course teachers may update the grade descriptors as and whenever necessary. Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.)
outcome: After the course, participants will be able to:  1. understand recent school management reforms in Hong Kong and their impacts on preschools and kindergartens; 2. examine various roles of early childhood teachers in relation to school reforms and school-based management; 3. have a basic understanding of various school management concepts and their application in daily operation of early childhood education institutions;  4. identify areas for school improvement based on information gathered from annual school self-evaluation and external school review; 5. reflect critically on individual competency, school practices and capacity for change by linking theories and practices in the context of early childhood education.
syllabus: Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.
required_readings: Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.
recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.

title: Parental Involvement in Young Children’s Education
description: The course aims to help participants develop competency in working with families and communities for young children’s education. Special emphasis is placed upon the roles of parents in fostering children’s development, dynamics of the parents-teacher relationship, policies of home school collaboration under the current and local educational reform, and practices for enhancing home-school-community collaboration within the changing local and international context.(Individual course teachers may update the grade descriptors as and whenever necessary. Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.)
outcome: After the course, students will be able to:  1. understand parents’ roles in young children education; 2. identify socio-economic factors related to parental involvement in young children’s education 3. demonstrate competency in enhancing home school communication for young children’s learning, such as academic, socio-emotional development; 4. demonstrate competency in planning parental involvement in school activities; 5. demonstrate competence in strengthening collaboration with parents and community, including promoting their understanding on quality ECE and contribute in implementing early children curriculum .
syllabus: 1. Overview of Parental Involvement in Children’s Education 2. Theoretical Review of HSC collaboration  3. Understanding the Constraints and Possibilities of Parents of Different Background 4. Comprehensive Model of HSC collaboration and Its’ impact on Student Learning 5. Innovative ideas on Parenting 6. Effective Communication with parents and families 7. Mobilizing School Volunteers 8. Decision Making and Participation in PTA 9. Collaborating with the community  10. Strategic Plan for Parental Involvement  Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.
required_readings: Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.
recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.

title: Early Childhood Development
description: This course aims to introduce the main aspects of child development, including physical, cognitive, affective and social development, from birth to the eighth year of age. The development of various competencies in early childhood and the factors that affect the development will be illuminated with major developmental theories/perspectives and relevant empirical research. The course will also help students appreciate that a deep understanding of child development can inform the practice of early childhood education, such as how to identify and cater for the needs of individual children effectively and how to conduct child observation and assessment appropriately.(Individual course teachers may update the grade descriptors as and whenever necessary. Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.)
outcome: A. Compare and contrast the perspectives of major developmental theories which influence early childhood education. B. Demonstrate knowledge of developmental capabilities and tasks at each stage of early childhood development. C. Practice methodological approaches including observations, interviews, and developmental assessments to understand children’s behaviors. D. Demonstrate the ability to summarize and to analyze collected information on young children’s development in theoretical contexts. E. Apply developmental theories and research results in practical situations when planning for instruction, or developing facilitative interactions with children. F. Appreciate developmental differences in individual children and understand how they influence classroom practice.
syllabus: Physical growth and brain development Cognitive development Social and emotional development Methodological approaches to understand young children’s development and behaviors
required_readings: For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.  Wittmer, D., Peterson, S. H., & Puckett, M. B. (2013). The young child: Development from prebirth through age eight (6th ed.) Upper Saddle River, NJ: Pearson Education Inc.

title: Supporting Young Children with Diverse Needs
description: This course employs a cross-disciplinary perspective to introduce important issues in supporting young children with diverse needs in mainstream school settings. First, contemporary policies and available support for young children with diverse needs in preschools will be examined. Second, the developmental characteristics and basic principles of early identification will be addressed. Most importantly, evidence based interventions for young children with diverse needs, in particular, those with difficulties in cognitive, communication, early literacy, social, behavioral and emotional development will be discussed. The 3-tier support model and home-school collaboration will be emphasized in delivering the interventions for those children in needs.(Individual course teachers may update the grade descriptors as and whenever necessary. Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.)
outcome: At the conclusion of the course, participants will be able to: 1. Have a deeper understanding of contemporary policies and support available for young children with special education needs. 2. Acquire basic knowledge of the characteristics and possible causes of various types of special needs in young children.  3. Acquire basic knowledge and skills to identify various kinds of special needs in young children. 4. Develop and provide effective support strategies according to the special needs of the students timely so as to enhance their development and learning in school. 5. Critically reflect on current issues related to the support of young students with diverse needs.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: Diverse needs & Service for pre-school children with special needs in Hong Kong 2. Support model for catering children with diverse needs & Developmental Coordination problem 3. Intellectual Development (cognitive and speech language) 4. Learning Development: difficulties in literacy development 5. Social-emotional Development (ADHD and ASD) 6. Support strategies at the school level and family level
required_readings: Mak, R. H.L, Lam, C. C. C., Ho, C.C.Y., & Wong, M. M. Y. (Eds). (2006). A primer in common developmental disabilities: Experience at Child Assessment Service, Hong Kong. Hong Kong: Child Assessment Service, Department of Health.  Sandall, S.R., Schwartz, I.S. (2008). Building blocks for teaching preschoolers with special needs. Paul H. Brookes Publishing Co. Gestwicki, C. (2014). Developmentally appropriate practice (5th Ed.). recommended_readings: 李麗梅（2008）。《不一樣的孩子：認識及培育學習差異兒童》。香港：中文大學出版社。  到校學前康復服務試驗計劃 http://www.swd.gov.hk/oprs/index_tc.htm  For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.

title: Teaching Fundamental Movement Skills and Rhythmic Activity for Young Children
description: This course enables students to acquire the necessary skills and knowledge to plan and implement an effective movement program considered developmentally appropriate for preschool classrooms to support the development of physical literacy in young children. Students will be introduced to both theoretical and applied aspects of movement education for young children in different development stages, as well as being put through an interactive learning process to understand to understand the current practices in evaluating motor behaviors of the early years. Students will also learn to identify creative and innovative solutions to support the development of physical literacy in young children using a range of fundamental movement skills (FMS) and rhythmic activities.Grade Descriptor: [A] The work is of outstanding quality, meeting the expectations for quality of teaching standards at a high level. The teacher shows an ability to carry out or exemplify the standards consistently. [B] The work is of good quality, meeting the expectations for quality of teaching standards at a good level. The teacher shows an ability to carry out or exemplify the standards most of the time. [C] The work is of satisfactory quality, meeting the expectations for quality of teaching standards at an adequate level. The teacher shows an ability to carry out or exemplify the standards; but not always consistently and requires improvement in teaching quality. [D] The work is of sufficient quality, meeting the expectations for quality of teaching standards at an acceptable level. The teacher shows an ability to carry out or exemplify the standards; but always shows flaws and requires significant improvement in teaching quality. [F] The work is of limited quality, fails to meet the expectations for quality of teaching standards at an acceptable level. The teacher cannot carry out or exemplify the standards with serious recurring teaching mistakes.(Individual course teachers may update the grade descriptors as and whenever necessary. Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.)
outcome: Upon the completion of the course, students should be able to: 1. Understand child physical, cognitive and affective development and underpinning theories of motor skill learning and development in young children. 2. Understand FMS and movement concepts, and describe how they interact with one another to promote acquisition of FMS and physical literacy in children. 3. Demonstrate understanding of movement concepts and the skill components for teaching and assessment of young children’s motor proficiency in a variety of FMS. 4. Identify /diagnose the problems, and develop creative and innovative solutions to the problems of motor skill acquisition among young children. 5. Plan and deliver developmentally appropriate physical activities in a critical and innovative approach to support physical, cognitive and affective development of young children. 6. Demonstrate application of professional ethics and values in planning and delivering developmentally appropriate physical activities for young children.
syllabus: • Understanding Movement Learning • Fundamental Movement Skills and Components of Movement Concepts • Teaching and Learning of Fundamental Movement Skills and Developmental Progressions • Overview of Physical Literacy and Fundamental Movement Skills • Movement and Music in the Early Years • Physical Activity, Fitness and Children’s Health • Assessment Strategies for Motor Development
required_readings: Rae, P. (2013). Experiences in Movement & Music: Birth to Age 8 (5th ed.). Belmont, California: Wadsworth Cengage Learning.
recommended_readings: Books 1. Abels, K. W., & Bridges, J. M. (2010). In Bridges J. M. (Ed.), Teaching Movement Education: Foundations for Active Lifestyles. Champaign, IL: Human Kinetics. 2. title: Teaching Practicum
description: Teaching Practicum (TP) is an integral part of the Postgraduate Diploma in Education (Early Childhood Education) Programme. It provides opportunities for students to put theory into classroom practice. In order to support students’ professional development, practicum supervision will be conducted by the Faculty’s TP supervisors during the TP period. TP supervisors will assess students through formative and summative assessment, taking into consideration students’ teaching performance as well as their professional behaviour and attitude.(Individual course teachers may update the grade descriptors as and whenever necessary. Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.)
outcome: The intended Learning Outcomes of TP are that students will:  (1) demonstrate teaching competence ;  (2) integrate and apply pedagogical content knowledge in practice;  (3) apply concepts of reflective practice to authentic classroom and  (4) develop appropriate attitudes and values of a qualified teacher.
recommended_readings: 呂木琳(1998)：《敎學視導：理論與實務》，台北市：五南圖書出版公司。 李坤崇(2006)：《教學評量》，台北市：心理出版社股份有限公司。 吳培源(2005)：《教學視導：觀念、知能與實務》，台北市：心理出版社股份有限公司。 張清濱(2005)：《教學視導與評鑑》，台北：五南圖書出版股份有限公司。 張德銳(1996)：《發展性敎師評鑑系統》，台北 : 五南圖書出版公司。 黃政傑、張芬芬主編(2001)：《學為良師：在敎育實習中成長》，台北市：師大書苑有限公司。 黃政傑主編(1996)：《敎學評量》，台北市：師大書苑有限公司。 賴清標主編(2001)：《教育實習教學案例》，台北：五南圖書出版公司。 Annette L. Breaux, A.L. (2013). 101 "answers" for new teachers & their mentors: effective teaching tips for daily classroom use. New York: Routledge. Borich, G.D. & Tombari, M.L. (2004).
